author: Primrose Riordan
title: Malcolm Turnbull expected to keep using private email
text:
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's use of a private email account has been questioned. Alex Ellinghausen Civil liberties advocates have also raised concerns, with open government expert, Craig Thomler, saying: "having a Minister or PM operate a private email server, outside government security and archiving is bad for government".
Labor's Shadow Attorney-General said: "it would be concerning if government ministers were using private email or messaging services to evade their obligations under FOI law."
The questions come after US Democratic Party presidential candidate Hillary Clinton was forced to apologise for her use of a private email account while she was secretary of state.
Malcolm Turnbull dismissed security and freedom on information fears saying he did not use email and apps for classified information, and his office said the email is anchored by a server located in Australia.
JUST IN: Defence Minister Kevin Andrews, tipped to be moved out of his portfolio, is set to address the media at 2.45pm....
Posted by Financial Review - Federal politics on Saturday, 19 September 2015 "National classified information can't be and is not and has not been used, transmitted by me on services other than those approved for it," he said.
Mr Turnbull did not show any intention of stopping using the services on Friday.
"I use a variety of forms of messaging. I am very careful about security and I use my private non-Government email is obviously one that I've had for many years and many people can reach me that way," he said.
On Friday he acknowledged ones that self-destructed may be impossible to retrieve.
"Then there probably won't be a record to disclose," he said.
He has also said he uses WhatsApp.
"I use WhatsApp ... because they're superior over-the-top messaging platforms," he said in March.
He said he used them as SMS was not as secure, and could reside in a telco's servers even if they had been deleted by the user.
"Probably the least secure form of messaging is SMS or text messaging because the messages are not encrypted in transit and they're not encrypted on the telco's server," he said.
Other tech experts have raised concerns about the transparency of the Wickr app itself.
Mr Turnbull said all communications are subject to FoI requests, whatever platform they were on.
"All communications or records of a minister which relate to his or her duties are (subject to many exemptions) potentially subject to FoI whether it is on SMS, a private email server or a government email server," the statement said.
Mr Turnbull is a tech-enthusiast and uses a number of social media – including Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram – many of which can be used to send private messages, and have geo-location functions.
Mr Turnbull's Instagram posts often include his location, for example.
The Prime Minister's department is governed by a Protective Security Policy Framework which raises concerns about employees using private email.
"Allowing staff to access web–based email services can pose a security risk if there are insufficient malicious web content filtering controls," the manual says.
